items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Receive First Reading of New Board Policy #5353 Pertaining to Student LockersIt is recommended that the Board of Trustees review proposed Board Policy 5353.  The East Side Union High School District shall allow each school site to determine the need for school lockers on the campus in accordance with the school site safety plan.The determination will be based on:  Safety and security concerns  Instructional considerations  Resource availability  Physical and structural site capability  It is recommended that no student should carry books totaling more than 15% of his/her total body weight at any given time.Lockers on a school campus are a convenience for students and therefore schools are not required to have them.  Any school within the district that has lockers on its campus will enforce a policy outlining the rights, responsibilities and liabilities of both student and school.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive and review proposed policy 5353 - Student Lockers.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Award the Request for Proposals (RFP), RFP-01-08-09, for the Student Information System (SIS) and to Enter into a Five-Year Contract with Infinite CampusSUMMARYThe District is pleased to present to the Board of Trustees the following recommendation for the award of the RFP-01-08-09 for the replacement of the SIS.  The District underwent a thorough RFP.  The development of the RFP began several months prior to the release of the RFP.  A diverse group of district employees lead by Information Technology previewed the latest products available and compared them to the District’s experience with the existing SIS.  The current SIS will no longer be supported as of 2010 thereby forcing the District to procure an alternative SIS.  Out of the review of the latest products, a very well defined Scope of Work Matrix was developed.The RFP was released on November 18, 2008 and closed on December 17, 2008.  The RFP was advertised in a local newspaper and was announced at an IT conference where most if not all of vendors who provide this type of software were present. The District received nine responsive and responsible proposals.  The first step in the evaluation process was to score each of the nine proposals submitted to the District.  The proposals were scored in accordance with the scoring matrix in the RFP.  Those vendors who received a score of 60% or higher of the possible 80% (the remaining 20% was reserved for the oral interviews/demonstrations) were asked to give a demonstration: five vendors received a score of 60% or higher.The second and final step in the evaluation process was to conduct the oral interviews/ demonstrations. A 10 member panel was assembled which consisted of representatives from counseling, teachers, professional development, administration, attendance accounting, and IT.  All five vendors were scored on their demonstrations.All of the scores were added together and the vendor who received the highest score of 87% is Infinite Campus.  The second highest score was 78%.FISCAL IMPACT $457,000.00 Initial Costs$214,000.00 Ongoing Annual CostsFUNDING SOURCEMeasure EGeneral FundRECOMMENDATIONSIt is recommended that the Board of Trustees award the Request for Proposals (RFP), RFP-01-08-09, for the Student Information System (SIS) and to Enter into a Five-Year contract with Infinite Campus.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve the Merging of Measure G and Measure E Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committees to Form One CommitteeIn compliance with the Strict Accountability in Local School Construction Bonds Act of 2000 (“Strict Accountability Act”), the ESUHSD Board of Trustees formed an independent Citizens’ Oversight Committee (“CBOC”) for Measure G and Measure E, to report to the public on the proper expenditure of bond funds.The Board of Trustees approved the Measure G Citizens Bond Oversight Committee in April 2002 and Measure E Citizens Bond Oversight Committee on April 17, 2008.  To capitalize on the extensive and valuable experience the Measure G CBOC members have, the Board of Trustees appointed the members of the Measure G CBOC to also sit as the Measure E CBOC and appointed additional members.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve consolidating the Measure G and E CBOC Oversight Committee into one committee.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approval of Measure E Prioritization ListThe Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District identified a goal of developing and implementing an Academic Master Plan (AMP) that would close the achievement gap while improving the overall academic performance of all students. The Academic Master Plan initiative was designed to guide District policy and practice through the year 2015 by integrating programs, services, and facilities for 21st century student success.The three major areas of focus for the AMP included:Identification of specific programs and projects that would meet the needs of the 21st century studentIdentification of practices and programs to narrow the achievement gap and meet the requirement of Program ImprovementRecommendations on the utilization of Measure E fundsThe plan included the identification of an intersection between academic programs and renovated and newly constructed facilities, technology and equipment that provides the district with an innovative approach to equitably prioritizing resources.Specific criteria were developed by a team of stakeholders, including the Academic Master Plan working group, district facility staff, Superintendent and cabinet, School Site Council, and campus administrators.A Project Ranking & Pricing Process that is standardized, equitable and stakeholder driven was developed based on the Academic Master Plan categories of Health, Safety & ADA, Capacity, Technology, Outdoor / Athletic Spaces, Collaborative Spaces, and Specialty Spaces. The Academic Master Plan criteria used to establish standardized criteria for ranking projects was used. The criteria was based on consistency of request, reasonable and affordable, impact on the greatest number of students, timing of projects – long & short, addressing the achievement gap, parity and equity, and cost savings measures. Sources of District and campus needs were based on the Academic Master Plan, Technology Master Plan, Measure G Master Plan, Preliminary Needs Assessment, Maintenance & Operations Deferred Maintenance Plan, and School Site Council priorities.The Measure E Campus Priority project evaluation was based on the above process.Following project reviews with each of the comprehensive campuses, the campuses presented their priorities to the Board on February 7, 2009.The cabinet reviewed the campus list of projects and provided an adjusted order of priorities.FISCAL IMPACT:Campus Projects Total   $215,897,865.00District-Wide Technology  $27,460,000.00FUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Measure E Prioritization List.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTWeek of the School AdministratorMarch 1-7, 2009Resolution #2008-2009-19WHEREAS, Leadership Matters for California’s public education system and the more than 6 million students it serves;WHEREAS, School administrators are passionate, lifelong learners who believe in the value of quality public education, andWHEREAS, The title “school administrator” is a broad term used to define many education leadership posts. Superintendents, assistant superintendents, principals, assistant principals, special education and adult education leaders, curriculum and assessment leaders, school business officials, classified educational leaders, and other school district employees are considered administrators; andWHEREAS, providing quality service for student success is paramount for the profession; andWHEREAS, Most school administrators began their careers as teachers. The average administrator has served in public education for more than a decade. Most of California’s superintendents have served in education for more than 20 years. Such experience is beneficial in their work to effectively and efficiently lead public education and improve student achievement; andWHEREAS, Public schools operate with lean management systems. Across the nation, public schools employ fewer managers and supervisors than most public and private sector industries including transportation, food service, manufacturing, utilities, construction, publishing and public administration; andWHEREAS, School leaders depend on a network of support from school communities – fellow administrators, teachers, parents, students, businesses, community members, board trustees, colleges and universities, community and faith-based organizations, elected officials and district and county staff and resources – to promote ongoing student achievement and school success; andWHEREAS, Research shows great schools are led by great principals, and great districts are led by great superintendents. These site leaders are supported by extensive administrative networks throughout the state; andWHEREAS, the State of California has declared the first full week of March as the “Week of the School Administrator” in Education Code 44015.1; andWHEREAS, The future of California’s public education system depends upon the quality of its leadership; now thereforeTHEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, by the East Side Union High School District that all school leaders be commended for the contributions they make to successful student achievement.PASSED AND ADOPTED this 19th day of February, 2009 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. AYES:   ________NOES:  ________ABSENT:  ______ABSTAIN:  ______I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on February 19, 2009._________________________ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTNational African American History MonthFebruary 2009Resolution #2008-2009-20WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District takes pride in joining citizens throughout the country in recognizing February of 2009 as National African American History Month; andWHEREAS, African American History Month is an opportunity to share the historical and present contributions of African Americans, andWHEREAS, African American History Month began as "Negro History Week" in February 1926 as in the United States as supplement to the school curriculum, through the work of African American scholar, Dr. Carter G. Woodson; his aim was to encourage a greater awareness and understanding of the African experience and contributions in America, Africa and throughout the world; andWHEREAS, later, in the 1960’s, the week expanded into Black History Month to commemorate, through community activities, a more balanced and accurate picture of Black History, and is celebrated yearly during the entire month of February, as it coincides with the birthdays of the great African American Leader Frederick Douglass (February 15) and Abraham Lincoln (February 12); andWHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District recognizes the significant contributions and huge advances African Americans have made, and continue to make in our community, state and the world, in such areas as education, medicine, art, culture, public service, economic and development, politics and human rights; we see the greatness of America in those who have risen above injustice and enriched our society; andWHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District in its continued effort to honor African American History Month and to enhance equity and diversity, will seek to make changes in all its language to replace the word "tolerance" with words like "acceptance, respect, inclusion and appreciation," whenever relating to equity and/or diversity;THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, the East Side Union High School District hereby proclaims February 2009 as National African American History Month. PASSED AND ADOPTED this 19th day of February, 2009 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. AYES:   ________NOES:  ________ABSENT:  ______ABSTAIN:  ______I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on February 19, 2009._________________________ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education StudentsDESCRIPTION: Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:1)	An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.2)	Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.3)	An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: Student A	Student B	Student C	Student D	Student E	Student FStudent G	Student H	Student I	Student J	Student K	Student LStudent M	Student N	Student O	Student P	Student Q	Student RStudent S	Student T	Student U	Student V	Student W	Student XStudent Y	Student Z	Student A2	Student B2	Student C2	Student D2	Student E2	Student F2Student G2	Student H2	Student I2	Student J2	Student K2	Student L2Student M2	Student N2	Student O2	Student P2	Student Q2	Student R2Student S2	Student T2	Student U2	Student V2	Student W2	Student X2Student Y2	Student Z2	Student A3	Student B3	Student C3	Student D3	Student E3	Student F3	Student G3	Student H3	Student I3 FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.
